For the rest of the week, he will buy plastic action figures which cost $2 each. How many total action figures will he have by the end of the week?

direct_answer.text:
First, find out how much was spent until Wednesday using wooden action figures priced at $5 apiece:
Amount spent = Quantity X Cost_per_unit
                    =  14635 × 5
                    ≈  $73,175
Then deduct this amount from initial funds:
Remaining Money = Initial Funds – Spent Until Wednesday
                      =  $66,715,200 – $73,175
                      ≈  $66,642,025
From Thursday (Friday, Saturday ,and Sunday), Peter spends equally divided among himself for other types ("Plastic"):
Daily Expense = Remaining Money / No. Of Weekdays Left
                         =  $66,642,025 / 4
                         ≈  $16,660,506.25
Total Money Used That Week = DailyExpense × noOfWeekDaysLeft
                            ≈  $16,660,506.25 × 4

Hence, only half goes toward purchasing wood blocks while another half stays intact. Therefore, up until Thursday evening, you managed to accumulate Wood Block Count=($5337216/5)/$5=$213488 .
After spending everything available on Plastic Action Figures priced at $2 apiece beginning from Friday morning, your inventory becomes PAF_count=(remaining Budget+half(Wood block sales))/$2=.
PAF_count=$(6671520/2)+$213488/2=${$3335760+$213488}/2

To solve this problem mathematically using logic puzzles would involve several steps considering all conditions leading up to and including Midweek (Wednesday), which was also hinted towards being pivotal. Here’s how you might approach solving similar problems systematically:

Step 1: Determine daily spend/earn rate according to original plan.
Originally, if Peter plans to allocate his $6671520 equally over one week (seven days) starting Tuesday, let's find out how much he planned to use per day initially:  
$6671520 / 7 days = approximately $952217.14 spent per day

Step 2: Calculate amount used through Monday evening.
Peter starts distributing his funds since Tuesday means no allocations happened right away, so still holds onto full balance. However, come Wednesday, he decided to split these funds into equal parts every single day. From Sunday night til ending Tuesday afternoon, three whole days pass, meaning he gets ready for another round of distribution tomorrow (Thursday):  
Initial Daily Fund Allocation = Total Available Balance / Number

direct_answer.text: Peter began distributing $6,671,520 evenly across seven days starting from Monday. This means he was allocating roughly $953,074 per day ($\frac{6671520}{7}$). Since Peter decided to spend half of this amount before Wednesday ends ("up unto Wednesday"), let's calculate how much he had allocated already for those two days plus Tuesday night into Wednesday morning. That makes for three full distributions since Sunday counts as well because no indication suggests otherwise. Hence, for three days, which amounts to $\frac{3}{7}$th of the original fund pool. Multiplying the daily allotment by three gives us $2,861,222 ($953,074 × 3)$. Half of this figure represents the spent amount, so Peter spent approximately $1,430,611 ($2,861,222 / 2$) buying wooden figurines at $5 each. Given the information, you can confirm whether your calculation matches reality through checking against any additional context provided outside this instruction set.
